title: How to write a story without dwelling over the wording of every single line - Quora

response.answer_text: Practice and experience — by writing daily. At first, you almost certainly will labor over every line, and you should. This is how you hone your craft. But as time goes on, and you become more experienced, the writing will come more naturally. Your mind will intuitively know what to write. Eventually, although you’ll still write and rewrite many lines, you’ll trust yourself on the other ones. It’s like when you first learn to drive a car. Those beginning trips are almost harrowing simply because there seems to be so much to pay attention to. You have pedals, a steering wheel, and instrument panels, and other cars and pedestrians and lights and signs. It’s all too much. But over time, your attention (your conscious attention) increasingly narrows to what really matters. Your subconscious attention is taking care of the routine stuff. You don’t need to think how far down to push the pedal; you just do it. Writing is like this. After time, a lot of it just flows and you develop a sense for which sentences and words to labor over. Thanks for the A2A — great question! [Answered: How do you write a story without dwelling over the wording of every single line?]

When the action or object or situation being described is routine, don’t strive for exceptional literary brilliance. Just say it, as: “She opened the car door and got in.” “He slipped the envelope in the mail slot.” When there is something significant about the action or object, then add more description. “She stepped up to the car and gripped the door handle nervously, looking up at the gathering storm clouds, dark masses that moved ominously overhead, a sure sign of rain.”
